task.name: media-info-0.7
task.title: Make media-info work with the 0.7.x tagging stuff
task.description: During 0.7, tag handling has been rewritten. media-info needs to be fixed to be able to extract tags using the new interface.
task.why: The new tagging code is more flexible, and the old one has been deprecated. Fixing media-info will also fix problems with nautilus-media in GNOME.
task.how: The tag extraction code is used in gst-launch. media-info has a stateful parser. The state where it looks for metadata needs to be changed to use the new tagging interface. You can verify if it works by running media-info-test on tagged audio files.
task.difficulty: MEDIUM - tag extraction is stable but new and not documented yet.

task.name: 686basicomega
task.title: Make basicomega scheduler work with i686 glibc
task.description: One of the fastest schedulers we have is the one called basicomega. Unfortunatly we have been bared from using it as the default for quite a while because it segfaults when you use a version of glibc that has been compiled with -march=686. This means that the standard glibc used with major distributions like Mandrake and Red Hat cause this scheduler to crash.
task.why: Context switching is one of the tasks the scheduler does most. And the faster the better. For many heavy applications being able to use this scheduler would be a great boon.
task.how:
If we knew we would have fixed it long ago ourselves. Andy Wingo says the following:
"As you know, omega cothreads uses up the stack in pieces, one piece per element. It assumes that it has 2M of stack space to work with, divided into 16 pieces (see the top of cothreads.c). Now this 2M size is arbitrary, and based on the old pre-i686 glibc's default stack size. For new threads in gstthread.c, we explicitly ask for a 2M stack. But for the main thread, we never try to query or even change the size with getrlimit/setrlimit(2). I would suggest looking here for a solution (try calling setrlimit(RLIMIT_STACK,rlim_struct_for_2M).
So what might be happening is too many (more than 8) elements are being put into the main thread and it's trying to use memory that doesn't belong to it.Note also that the STACK_SIZE macro in cothreads.c and the STACK_SIZE macro in gstthread.c depend on each other.
Just keep in mind the saying about the worth of free advice :-)"
